conclusion: An electromagnetic railgun fire truck launches fire extinguishing projectiles into high-rise buildings using electromagnetic propulsion technology.
Energy stored in capacitors is converted into kinetic energy of the projectile through electromagnetic induction.
By setting the working voltage of the energy storage capacitors, the desired muzzle velocity of the projectile can be achieved.
The railgun is aimed directly at a high-rise building with a horizontal distance L=60m between them.
The muzzle velocity of the projectile is v0=50m/s, and the launch angle relative to the horizontal plane is θ=53°.
Neglecting the height of the railgun above the ground and air resistance, and taking the acceleration due to gravity as g=10m/s², and sin53°=0.8.
Determine the height H above the ground at which the fire extinguishing projectile hits the high-rise building.
The image shows an electromagnetic railgun fire truck and a diagram illustrating the projectile's trajectory towards a high-rise building.
Calculate the horizontal component of the initial velocity using v_x0 = v_0 cos(θ) resulting in v_x0 = 30 m/s.
Calculate the time it takes for the projectile to travel the horizontal distance using t = L/v_x0 resulting in t = 2 s.
Calculate the vertical component of the initial velocity using v_y0 = v_0 sin(θ) resulting in v_y0 = 40 m/s.
Calculate the height H above the ground at which the projectile hits the high-rise building using H = v_y0 t - (1/2) g t² resulting in H = 60 m.
